content.content:
1â†’# Lore
     2â†’
     3â†’Meta-layer for coordinating projects in a development directory.
     4â†’
     5â†’## What This Is
     6â†’
     7â†’Lore is the hub that knows about all projects in your development directory:
     8â†’
     9â†’- **Registry**: What projects exist (via mani), their roles, relationships
    10â†’- **Clusters**: Groups of projects that work together (like council)
    11â†’- **Patterns**: Reusable patterns extracted from projects
    12â†’- **Context**: Cross-project handoff notes and tasks
    13â†’
    14â†’## Architecture
    15â†’
    16â†’**mani** knows _what exists_. **Lore** knows _why it matters_.
    17â†’
    18â†’Project existence and basic metadata live in **mani** (`~/dev/mani.yaml`). Lore adds the enrichment layer: roles, contracts, cluster choreography, relationship tracking, and context assembly.
    19â†’
    20â†’```
    21â†’~/dev/mani.yaml          Source of truth for project existence
    22â†’    |
    23â†’    +-- mani CLI             list, sync, exec, TUI
    24â†’    |
    25â†’~/dev/lore/
    26â†’    +-- registry/
    27â†’    |   +-- metadata.yaml    Role, contracts, components, links
    28â†’    |   +-- clusters.yaml    Pipeline choreography, data flow
    29â†’    |   +-- relationships.yaml  Rich dependency metadata
    30â†’    +-- scripts/
    31â†’        +-- lore-cli.sh   show, context, validate, sync
    32â†’```
    33â†’
    34â†’## Prerequisites
    35â†’
    36â†’```bash
    37â†’brew install yq jq mani
    38â†’```
    39â†’
    40â†’## Configuration
    41â†’
    42â†’| Variable    | Default           | Purpose                     |
    43â†’| ----------- | ----------------- | --------------------------- |
    44â†’| `MANI_FILE` | `~/dev/mani.yaml` | Override mani.yaml location |
    45â†’
    46â†’Scripts derive the workspace root from lore's own location. Override `MANI_FILE` to point elsewhere.
    47â†’
    48â†’- `yq` (Go version, https://github.com/mikefarah/yq) v4.52+
    49â†’- `jq` (https://jqlang.github.io/jq/) v1.7+
    50â†’- `mani` (https://github.com/alajmo/mani) v0.31+
    51â†’
    52â†’## Quick Start
    53â†’
    54â†’```bash
    55â†’# List all projects (mani)
    56â†’cd ~/dev && mani list projects
    57â†’
    58â†’# Filter by type, cluster, or tag
    59â†’mani list projects --tags type:orchestrator
    60â†’mani list projects --tags cluster:council
    61â†’mani list projects --tags "lang:rust"
    62â†’
    63â†’# Show enriched project details (lore)
    64â†’./scripts/lore-cli.sh show council
    65â†’
    66â†’# Assemble agent context bundle
    67â†’./scripts/lore-cli.sh context flow
    68â†’```
    69â†’
    70â†’Or explore the raw YAML files directly:
    71â†’
    72â†’```bash
    73â†’cat ~/dev/mani.yaml                 # All projects with tags
    74â†’cat registry/metadata.yaml          # Roles, contracts, components
    75â†’cat registry/clusters.yaml          # Cluster definitions
    76â†’cat registry/relationships.yaml     # Dependencies
    77â†’```
    78â†’
    79â†’## For Agents
    80â†’
    81â†’Read `CLAUDE.md` first -- it's your entry point to the system.
    82â†’
    83â†’## Structure
    84â†’
    85â†’```
    86â†’~/dev/mani.yaml            # Project existence, paths, tags (outside lore repo)
    87â†’
    88â†’lore/
    89â†’+-- CLAUDE.md              # Agent entry point
    90â†’+-- SYSTEM.md              # Architecture map
    91â†’+-- contracts/
    92â†’|   +-- ENTIRE_BRIDGE_CONTRACT.md  # Entire checkpoint format spec
    93â†’+-- registry/
    94â†’|   +-- metadata.yaml      # Roles, contracts, components, links
    95â†’|   +-- clusters.yaml      # Cluster definitions
    96â†’|   +-- relationships.yaml # Dependencies
    97â†’|   +-- contracts.yaml     # Contract locations and status
    98â†’+-- patterns/              # Reusable patterns
    99â†’+-- context/               # Cross-project coordination
   100â†’|   +-- HANDOFF.md         # Handoff notes
   101â†’|   +-- CHECKLIST.md       # Operational maturity checklist
   102â†’+-- scripts/
   103â†’    +-- lore-cli.sh     # show, context, validate, sync
   104â†’    +-- validate-registry.sh  # Registry consistency checks
   105â†’    +-- migrate-to-mani.sh    # One-time migration (historical)
   106â†’```
   107â†’
   108â†’## Adding Projects
   109â†’
   110â†’### Add to mani
   111â†’
   112â†’Edit `~/dev/mani.yaml` directly. For projects with a `url` field, `mani sync` clones them locally.
   113â†’
   114â†’```yaml
   115â†’projects:
   116â†’  my-project:
   117â†’    path: my-project
   118â†’    desc: What this project does
   119â†’    tags: [type:library, lang:rust, status:active, my-tag]
   120â†’```
   121â†’
   122â†’### Tag encoding
   123â†’
   124â†’| Prefix     | Values                                                                     |
   125â†’| ---------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
   126â†’| `type:`    | orchestrator, library, application, service, tool, infrastructure, cluster |
   127â†’| `lang:`    | rust, shell, go, typescript, python, markdown                              |
   128â†’| `status:`  | active, wip, archived, deprecated                                          |
   129â†’| `cluster:` | orchestration, council, forge                                              |
   130â†’| (none)     | Free-form tags: agents, memory, cli, tui, etc.                             |
   131â†’
   132â†’### Add metadata (optional)
   133â†’
   134â†’If the project has a role, contracts, or components, add to `registry/metadata.yaml`:
   135â†’
   136â†’```yaml
   137â†’metadata:
   138â†’  my-project:
   139â†’    role: purpose-within-cluster
   140â†’    contracts:
   141â†’      exposes:
   142â†’        - MY_CONTRACT.md
   143â†’```
   144â†’
   145â†’### Join a cluster
   146â†’
   147â†’1. Add `cluster:<name>` tag in `mani.yaml`
   148â†’2. Add component entry in `registry/clusters.yaml`
   149â†’3. Add relationships in `registry/relationships.yaml`
   150â†’
   151â†’## Registry Validation
   152â†’
   153â†’```bash
   154â†’# Run all validations
   155â†’./scripts/validate-registry.sh
   156â†’
   157â†’# Or via lore CLI
   158â†’./scripts/lore-cli.sh validate
   159â†’```
   160â†’
   161â†’### Validations Performed
   162â†’
   163â†’| Validation        | Description                                                                                 |
   164â†’| ----------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
   165â†’| **Files**         | All registry files exist (mani.yaml, metadata.yaml, clusters.yaml, relationships.yaml)      |
   166â†’| **Paths**         | Project paths exist on the filesystem                                                       |
   167â†’| **Metadata**      | All metadata.yaml projects exist in mani.yaml                                               |
   168â†’| **Clusters**      | Cluster components exist in mani.yaml; projects with cluster: tags are listed as components |
   169â†’| **Relationships** | Dependency targets in relationships.yaml exist in mani.yaml                                 |
   170â†’| **Tag Schema**    | All projects have required tag prefixes: type:, lang:, status:                              |
   171â†’
   172â†’### Output Format
   173â†’
   174â†’```
   175â†’Validating registry...
   176â†’[PASS] All registry files exist
   177â†’[PASS] Path validation - all project paths are accessible
   178â†’[WARN] Path not accessible: ~/dev/some-project (project: some-project)
   179â†’[FAIL] metadata.yaml references 'foo' which does not exist in mani.yaml
   180â†’
   181â†’Summary: 2 passed, 1 warning, 1 failed
   182â†’```
   183â†’
   184â†’### Exit Codes
   185â†’
   186â†’- **0**: All validations passed (warnings are allowed)
   187â†’- **1**: One or more validations failed
   188â†’
   189â†’## CLI Reference
   190â†’
   191â†’The `lore` CLI (`scripts/lore-cli.sh`) handles enrichment on top of mani.
   192â†’
   193â†’### Commands
   194â†’
   195â†’| Command             | Description                                                 |
   196â†’| ------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------- |
   197â†’| `show <project>`    | Show enriched details (basics + metadata + deps)            |
   198â†’| `context <project>` | Assemble full context bundle for agent onboarding           |
   199â†’| `validate`          | Validate registry consistency                               |
   200â†’| `sync`              | Warn if metadata.yaml references are missing from mani.yaml |
   201â†’
   202â†’### lore show
   203â†’
   204â†’Display enriched information from all sources: mani.yaml (basics), metadata.yaml (role/contracts), clusters.yaml (pipeline position), relationships.yaml (dependencies).
   205â†’
   206â†’```bash
   207â†’./scripts/lore-cli.sh show council
   208â†’./scripts/lore-cli.sh show agent-of-empires
   209â†’```
   210â†’
   211â†’### lore context
   212â†’
   213â†’Assemble a focused context bundle for agent onboarding. Plain markdown output.
   214â†’
   215â†’Sections: Basics, Dependencies, Depended On By, Cluster (pipeline, data flow, principles), Contracts, Recent Handoffs, Entry Point.
   216â†’
   217â†’```bash
   218â†’./scripts/lore-cli.sh context flow
   219â†’./scripts/lore-cli.sh context oracle
   220â†’```
   221â†’

content.content:
1â†’# Mirror
     2â†’
     3â†’Judgment capture and pattern extraction CLI.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Build
     6â†’
     7â†’```
     8â†’make build      # Build to ./build/mirror
     9â†’make install    # Build and copy to ~/bin/mirror
    10â†’make test       # Run all tests
    11â†’make sync       # Sync patterns to Lineage via scripts/mirror-yeoman.sh
    12â†’make fmt        # Format Go source
    13â†’make lint       # Run golangci-lint
    14â†’```
    15â†’
    16â†’## Architecture
    17â†’
    18â†’- `cmd/mirror/` -- Entry point. Wires Cobra root command, registers subcommands from `internal/cli`.
    19â†’- `internal/cli/` -- One file per command (add, list, search, edit, patterns, principles, reflect, weekly).
    20â†’- `internal/judgment/` -- Domain model (`model.go`) and YAML persistence (`store.go`).
    21â†’
    22â†’## Conventions
    23â†’
    24â†’- **Persistence**: YAML files in `~/.mirror/` (judgments.yaml, patterns.yaml, principles/).
    25â†’- **IDs**: `YYYY-MM-DD-NNN` format, sequential per day.
    26â†’- **Categories**: `architecture`, `process`, `people`, `tradeoff`, `principle` (lowercase string enums).
    27â†’- **Pattern lifecycle**: `pattern` -> `principle` -> `deprecated`.
    28â†’- **Dependencies**: Cobra for CLI, yaml.v3 for serialization. No other runtime deps.
    29â†’
    30â†’## Design Decisions
    31â†’
    32â†’- YAML over JSON/SQL for human-readability and git-friendliness.
    33â†’- Filesystem persistence keeps the tool dependency-free and offline-capable.
    34â†’- Yeoman sync to Lineage runs manually via `make sync`, not automatically.
    35â†’
    36â†’## Known Gaps
    37â†’
    38â†’- No tests exist yet. `make test` passes vacuously.
    39â†’

<system-reminder>

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

content.content:
1â†’# mirror - Judgment Capture Tool
     2â†’
     3â†’AI commoditizes execution. What remains scarce is judgment.
     4â†’
     5â†’`mirror` makes your judgment visible, refineable, and compoundable.
     6â†’
     7â†’## Installation
     8â†’
     9â†’```bash
    10â†’cd ~/dev/mirror
    11â†’make install
    12â†’```
    13â†’
    14â†’## Usage
    15â†’
    16â†’### Capture a judgment
    17â†’
    18â†’```bash
    19â†’# Interactive mode
    20â†’mirror add
    21â†’
    22â†’# Quick capture with flags
    23â†’mirror add -t "Fail fast vs graceful degradation" -c architecture
    24â†’
    25â†’# Full JSON input (for Claude integration)
    26â†’mirror add --json '{"title": "API versioning", "category": "architecture", ...}'
    27â†’```
    28â†’
    29â†’### Browse judgments
    30â†’
    31â†’```bash
    32â†’mirror list                    # Recent 10 judgments
    33â†’mirror list -c architecture    # Filter by category
    34â†’mirror list -t observability   # Filter by tag
    35â†’mirror search "error handling" # Full-text search
    36â†’```
    37â†’
    38â†’### Surface patterns
    39â†’
    40â†’```bash
    41â†’mirror patterns               # Show patterns with 3+ occurrences
    42â†’mirror patterns -m 2          # Lower threshold
    43â†’mirror patterns --promote "Observability decisions"  # Graduate to principle
    44â†’mirror principles             # List extracted principles
    45â†’```
    46â†’
    47â†’### Reflection
    48â†’
    49â†’```bash
    50â†’mirror reflect   # Daily prompt
    51â†’mirror weekly    # Weekly summary
    52â†’```
    53â†’
    54â†’## Categories
    55â†’
    56â†’- **architecture** - System design, API choices, data models
    57â†’- **process** - How work gets done, communication patterns
    58â†’- **people** - Team dynamics, hiring, feedback
    59â†’- **tradeoff** - Explicit cost/benefit decisions
    60â†’- **principle** - Meta-decisions about how to decide
    61â†’
    62â†’## Data Storage
    63â†’
    64â†’All data stored in `~/.mirror/`:
    65â†’
    66â†’- `judgments.yaml` - All captured judgments
    67â†’- `patterns.yaml` - Detected patterns
    68â†’- `principles/` - Graduated principles as markdown
    69â†’
    70â†’## Claude Code Integration
    71â†’
    72â†’Use with the `/judgment` skill to capture decisions during coding sessions.
    73â†’

1â†’# Forge
     2â†’
     3â†’Spec â†’ prototype â†’ synthesis.
     4â†’
     5â†’Turns specs into proven solutions through parallel prototyping and synthesis.
     6â†’
     7â†’## Components
     8â†’
     9â†’| Project       | Role                                               |
    10â†’| ------------- | -------------------------------------------------- |
    11â†’| get-shit-done | Spec-driven development with structured milestones |
    12â†’| spec-trace    | Requirements traceability from specs to tests      |
    13â†’| coalesce      | Synthesize N prototypes into one solution          |
    14â†’
    15â†’## Flow
    16â†’
    17â†’```
    18â†’spec-trace    define requirements
    19â†’  â†“
    20â†’get-shit-done parallel prototypes with milestones
    21â†’  â†“
    22â†’coalesce      analyze, compare, synthesize
    23â†’```
    24â†’

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

content.content:
1â†’# Geordi
     2â†’
     3â†’Unified API and GUI for the agent ecosystem. Reads from Lineage, Lore, and
     4â†’Council to present a single view of decisions, patterns, projects, governance,
     5â†’and knowledge graph data.
     6â†’
     7â†’## Quick Start
     8â†’
     9â†’```bash
    10â†’make dev     # install deps + start server with auto-reload
    11â†’make run     # production mode (no reload)
    12â†’make check   # lint and type-check
    13â†’make help    # show all targets
    14â†’```
    15â†’
    16â†’- API docs: http://localhost:8420/docs
    17â†’- Graph explorer: http://localhost:8420/explorer
    18â†’- Governance dashboard: http://localhost:8420/dashboard
    19â†’- Decision journal: http://localhost:8420/journal
    20â†’- Project observatory: http://localhost:8420/observatory
    21â†’
    22â†’## Architecture
    23â†’
    24â†’Geordi is a read-heavy service. It reads data files directly (JSONL, JSON, YAML,
    25â†’markdown) from three upstream projects and wraps CLI commands for writes. No
    26â†’database, no data duplication.
    27â†’
    28â†’```
    29â†’Lineage (journal, graph, patterns, sessions)
    30â†’Lore    (mani.yaml, registry/*.yaml)           --> Geordi --> REST API + GUIs
    31â†’Council (seats, ADRs, initiatives, charter)
    32â†’```
    33â†’
    34â†’### File Layout
    35â†’
    36â†’```
    37â†’server.py          # FastAPI application (port 8420)
    38â†’explorer.html      # D3.js force-directed knowledge graph
    39â†’dashboard.html     # Governance dashboard with timeline
    40â†’journal.html       # Decision journal browser with filtering and chains
    41â†’observatory.html   # Project-centric context viewer
    42â†’pyproject.toml     # Project metadata and dependencies (uv)
    43â†’uv.lock            # Lockfile
    44â†’Makefile           # Dev commands
    45â†’```
    46â†’
    47â†’### Path Configuration
    48â†’
    49â†’Environment variables with defaults:
    50â†’
    51â†’| Variable      | Default         | Purpose               |
    52â†’| ------------- | --------------- | --------------------- |
    53â†’| `LINEAGE_DIR` | `~/dev/lineage` | Lineage installation  |
    54â†’| `LORE_DIR`    | `~/dev/lore`    | Lore registry         |
    55â†’| `COUNCIL_DIR` | `~/dev/council` | Council governance    |
    56â†’| `DEV_PATH`    | `~/dev`         | Root for all projects |
    57â†’
    58â†’### Endpoints
    59â†’
    60â†’40+ REST endpoints organized by system:
    61â†’
    62â†’- `/api/journal/*` -- decisions, search, stats
    63â†’- `/api/graph/*` -- nodes, edges, traversal, clusters
    64â†’- `/api/patterns/*` -- patterns, anti-patterns, suggestions
    65â†’- `/api/sessions/*` -- transfer sessions
    66â†’- `/api/lore/*` -- projects, clusters, relationships, contracts
    67â†’- `/api/council/*` -- seats, ADRs, initiatives, charter
    68â†’- `/api/search`, `/api/timeline`, `/api/health`, `/api/stats`
    69â†’
    70â†’## Coding Conventions
    71â†’
    72â†’- Python 3.10+, type hints everywhere
    73â†’- Pydantic models for request/response shapes
    74â†’- Direct file I/O for reads, shell subprocess for writes
    75â†’- CORS enabled (all origins for now)
    76â†’- No authentication (local service)
    77â†’
    78â†’## Part of the Ecosystem
    79â†’
    80â†’Tracked in ~/dev/geordi. Reads from: Lineage, Lore, Council.
    81â†’

1â†’# l3m
     2â†’
     3â†’CLI toolkit for managing and benchmarking local LLMs across Ollama and MLX backends on Apple Silicon.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Install
     6â†’
     7â†’```bash
     8â†’uv sync                        # core deps (Ollama support)
     9â†’uv sync --extra mlx            # + MLX backend (Apple Silicon)
    10â†’uv tool install -e .           # global `l3m` command
    11â†’```
    12â†’
    13â†’## Commands
    14â†’
    15â†’### Model management
    16â†’
    17â†’```bash
    18â†’l3m list                       # models across all backends
    19â†’l3m list --backend ollama      # filter by backend
    20â†’l3m pull qwen3:14b             # install to default backend
    21â†’l3m pull qwen3:14b -b mlx     # install to specific backend
    22â†’l3m rm qwen3:14b               # remove a model
    23â†’l3m disk                       # disk usage by backend
    24â†’```
    25â†’
    26â†’### Inference
    27â†’
    28â†’```bash
    29â†’l3m chat qwen3:14b             # interactive streaming chat
    30â†’l3m chat qwen3:14b -b mlx     # force MLX backend
    31â†’l3m complete qwen3:14b -p "Explain monads in one paragraph"
    32â†’```
    33â†’
    34â†’### Benchmarking
    35â†’
    36â†’```bash
    37â†’l3m bench qwen3:14b            # benchmark on default backend
    38â†’l3m bench qwen3:14b --compare  # side-by-side Ollama vs MLX
    39â†’l3m bench qwen3:14b -n 256    # generate 256 tokens
    40â†’```
    41â†’
    42â†’Results save to `~/.local/share/l3m/benchmarks/` as JSON.
    43â†’
    44â†’### Configuration
    45â†’
    46â†’```bash
    47â†’l3m config --show
    48â†’l3m config --default-backend mlx
    49â†’```
    50â†’
    51â†’Config lives at `~/.config/l3m/config.toml`.
    52â†’
    53â†’## Architecture
    54â†’
    55â†’```
    56â†’src/l3m/
    57â†’â”œâ”€â”€ cli.py              # typer entrypoint
    58â†’â”œâ”€â”€ backends/
    59â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ base.py         # Backend protocol, ModelInfo, BenchResult
    60â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ollama.py       # Ollama REST API (httpx)
    61â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ mlx.py          # mlx-lm Python API (lazy-loaded)
    62â†’â”œâ”€â”€ models.py           # cross-backend model operations
    63â†’â”œâ”€â”€ bench.py            # benchmark runner + history
    64â†’â””â”€â”€ config.py           # TOML config + model aliases
    65â†’```
    66â†’
    67â†’Both backends implement the same protocol. The CLI dispatches to whichever backend the user selects (or the configured default). MLX imports are lazy so the CLI works even without `mlx-lm` installed.
    68â†’
    69â†’## Dependencies
    70â†’
    71â†’- **typer** â€” CLI framework
    72â†’- **httpx** â€” Ollama REST API client
    73â†’- **rich** â€” tables, progress bars
    74â†’- **pydantic** â€” config validation
    75â†’- **mlx-lm** (optional) â€” Apple Silicon inference
    76â†’

1â†’# Repository Guidelines
     2â†’
     3â†’## Project Structure & Module Organization
     4â†’
     5â†’- `src/main.rs`: binary entrypoint (`aoe`).
     6â†’- `src/lib.rs`: shared library code used by the CLI/TUI.
     7â†’- `src/cli/`: clap command handlers (e.g., `src/cli/add.rs`, `src/cli/session.rs`).
     8â†’- `src/tui/`: ratatui UI and input handling.
     9â†’- `src/session/`: session storage, configuration, and group management.
    10â†’- `src/tmux/`: tmux integration and status detection.
    11â†’- `src/process/`: OS-specific process handling (`macos.rs`, `linux.rs`).
    12â†’- `src/docker/`: Docker sandboxing and container management.
    13â†’- `src/git/`: git worktree operations and template resolution.
    14â†’- `src/update/`: version checking against GitHub releases.
    15â†’- `src/migrations/`: versioned data migrations for breaking changes (see below).
    16â†’- `tests/`: integration tests (`tests/*.rs`).
    17â†’- `docs/`: user-facing documentation and guides.
    18â†’- `scripts/`: installation and utility scripts.
    19â†’- `xtask/`: build automation workspace.
    20â†’
    21â†’## Build, Test, and Development Commands
    22â†’
    23â†’- `cargo build` / `cargo build --release`: compile (release binary at `target/release/aoe`).
    24â†’- `cargo build --profile dev-release`: faster optimized builds for local development. Skips LTO for quicker compile times while still producing an optimized binary. Use `--release` for final/CI builds.
    25â†’- `cargo run --release`: run from source; requires `tmux` installed.
    26â†’- `cargo check`: fast type-checking during development.
    27â†’- `cargo test`: run unit + integration tests (some tests skip if `tmux` is unavailable).
    28â†’- `cargo fmt`: format with rustfmt (run before pushing).
    29â†’- `cargo clippy`: lint (fix warnings unless thereâ€™s a strong reason not to).
    30â†’- Debug logging: `RUST_LOG=agent_of_empires=debug cargo run` (or `AGENT_OF_EMPIRES_DEBUG=1 cargo run`).
    31â†’- `just` (optional): runs common workflows. `just check` = fmt + clippy + test. `just build` = dev-release. `just install` = install from source.
    32â†’
    33â†’## Settings & Configuration
    34â†’
    35â†’- **Every configurable field must be editable in the settings TUI.** When adding a new config field to `SandboxConfig`, `WorktreeConfig`, etc., you must also:
    36â†’  1. Add a `FieldKey` variant in `src/tui/settings/fields.rs`
    37â†’  2. Add a `SettingField` entry in the corresponding `build_*_fields()` function
    38â†’  3. Wire up `apply_field_to_global()` and `apply_field_to_profile()`
    39â†’  4. Add a `clear_profile_override()` case in `src/tui/settings/input.rs`
    40â†’- Profile overrides (`*ConfigOverride` structs in `profile_config.rs`) must also include the new field with merge logic in `merge_configs()`.
    41â†’
    42â†’## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
    43â†’
    44â†’- Prefer "let the tools decide": keep code `cargo fmt`-clean and `cargo clippy`-clean.
    45â†’- **Never use emdashes (â€”)** in documentation or comments.
    46â†’- Rust naming: `snake_case` for modules/functions, `CamelCase` for types, `SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE` for constants.
    47â†’- Keep OS-specific logic in `src/process/{macos,linux}.rs` rather than sprinkling `cfg` checks.
    48â†’- Do not be concerned about maintaining backwards compatibility. You should not assume that it needs to be backwards compatible, but you should mention when you make a change that breaks backwards compatibility.
    49â†’- Add comments where they aid understanding, but remove obvious ones before finishing:
    50â†’  - **Keep**: comments explaining non-obvious formulas, layout structure documentation, or "why" something is done
    51â†’  - **Remove**: section headers that just name what the next line does (e.g., `// Render buttons` before `render_buttons()`), or comments restating the code
    52â†’
    53â†’## Testing Guidelines
    54â†’
    55â†’- Use unit tests in-module (`#[cfg(test)]`) for pure logic; use `tests/*.rs` for end-to-end behavior.
    56â†’- Tests must be deterministic and clean up after themselves (tmux tests should use unique names like `aoe_test_*`).
    57â†’- Avoid reading/writing real user state; prefer temp dirs (see `tempfile` usage in `src/session/storage.rs`).
    58â†’
    59â†’## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
    60â†’
    61â†’- Branch names: `feature/...`, `fix/...`, `docs/...`, `refactor/...`.
    62â†’- Commit messages: use conventional commit prefixes (`feat:`, `fix:`, `docs:`, `refactor:`).
    63â†’- PRs: include a clear â€œwhat/whyâ€, how you tested (`cargo test`, plus any manual tmux/TUI checks), and screenshots/recordings for UI changes.
    64â†’
    65â†’## Local Data & Configuration Tips
    66â†’
    67â†’- Runtime config/data location:
    68â†’  - **Linux**: `$REDACTED` (defaults to `~/.config/agent-of-empires/`)
    69â†’  - **macOS/Windows**: `~/.agent-of-empires/`
    70â†’- Keep user data out of commits. For repo-local experiments, use ignored paths like `./.agent-of-empires/`, `.env`, and `.mcp.json`.
    71â†’
    72â†’## Data Migrations
    73â†’
    74â†’When making breaking changes to stored data (file locations, config schema, etc.), use the migration system in `src/migrations/` instead of adding fallback/compatibility logic to the main code.
    75â†’
    76â†’**Why**: Keeps the main codebase clean. Legacy transition logic is isolated and clearly marked as such.
    77â†’
    78â†’**How it works**:
    79â†’1. A `.schema_version` file in the app directory tracks the current version
    80â†’2. On startup, `migrations::run_migrations()` runs any pending migrations in order
    81â†’3. Each migration bumps the version after completion
    82â†’
    83â†’**Adding a new migration**:
    84â†’
    85â†’1. Create `src/migrations/vNNN_description.rs`:
    86â†’   ```rust
    87â†’   use anyhow::Result;
    88â†’
    89â†’   pub fn run() -> Result<()> {
    90â†’       // Migration logic here
    91â†’       Ok(())
    92â†’   }
    93â†’   ```
    94â†’
    95â†’2. Update `src/migrations/mod.rs`:
    96â†’   ```rust
    97â†’   mod vNNN_description;
    98â†’
    99â†’   const CURRENT_VERSION: u32 = NNN;  // bump this
   100â†’
   101â†’   const MIGRATIONS: &[Migration] = &[
   102â†’       // ... existing migrations ...
   103â†’       Migration { version: NNN, name: "description", run: vNNN_description::run },
   104â†’   ];
   105â†’   ```
   106â†’
   107â†’**Guidelines**:
   108â†’- Migrations must be idempotent (safe to run multiple times)
   109â†’- Use `tracing::info!` to log what's happening
   110â†’- Platform-specific migrations should use `#[cfg(target_os = "...")]`
   111â†’- Test migrations by creating the old state manually and verifying the transition
   112â†’- Before finishing any feature request, make sure that you have run cargo fmt, clippy, and tests.
   113â†’

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

Now I have the full picture. Here's the map.

---

## The Grand Simplification

### Current State: 16 active projects

```
DATA LAYER                 CONTROL LAYER              ACTION LAYER
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€                 â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€              â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Lineage (memory)           Oracle/Telos (goals)       Bach (workers)
Lore (registry)            Neo (teams, sync)          Flow (state/phases)
Mirror (capture)           Council (governance)       Ralph (loop)
                           Forge (prototyping)

APPLICATIONS               TOOLS                      REFERENCE
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€               â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€                      â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Canary (prod app)          Duet (plugin)              Tutor (cheatsheets)
Agent-of-Empires (TUI)     l3m (local LLMs)
Geordi (API/GUI)
```

### What Praxis showed

Praxis proved that the data layer is one thing and the control layer is one thing. The separation into Lineage/Lore/Oracle was artificial â€” it split a single concern (persistent knowledge) across three repos with overlapping contracts.

### The collapses

**1. Telos (Oracle) â†’ Lineage**

Telos holds goals and missions. Praxis put `intent/` inside Lineage. Goals are just a type of structured knowledge â€” same as decisions, patterns, and observations. Lineage already has the storage primitives (JSONL for logs, JSON/YAML for documents, inbox for staging). Add `intent/` as a sixth component.

```
Lineage absorbs:
  oracle/goals/     â†’  lineage/intent/
  oracle/missions/  â†’  lineage/intent/  (missions are decomposed goals)
```

**2. Lore â†’ Lineage**

Lore holds the project registry â€” metadata about what exists, capabilities, relationships. Praxis put `registry/` inside Lineage. The graph component already tracks project nodes and edges. Lore's registry is the graph's source data.

```
Lineage absorbs:
  lore/registry/    â†’  lineage/registry/
  lore/metadata/    â†’  lineage/registry/
```

**3. Flow â†’ Neo**

Flow tracks milestones, phases, and task state. Neo already does team management and now sync/promote/start. Both are orchestration. Praxis replaced Flow with Neo's workflow commands. The `.flow/state.json` pattern moves into Neo's domain.

```
Neo absorbs:
  flow/state.json   â†’  neo/state/
  flow/commands/     â†’  neo/scripts/  (plan, execute, status)
```

**4. Mirror â†’ convention, not project**

Mirror is a capture location (`~/.mirror/*.md`). Neo's `sync.sh` already harvests from it. Mirror doesn't need to be a project â€” it's a directory convention. Document it in Neo's README and retire the repo.

```
~/.mirror/          stays as a directory convention
mirror/ repo        archived
```

### What stays separate

| Project | Why it survives |
|---------|----------------|
| **Lineage** | The data layer. Absorbs Telos, Lore. Single source of truth. |
| **Neo** | The control layer. Absorbs Flow. Orchestrates, delegates, syncs. |
| **Bach** | The execution layer. Stateless workers. Clean contract boundary. |
| **Ralph** | The loop driver. Thin, stateless, drives iteration. |
| **Council** | Governance. Advisory, not operational. Different concern. |
| **Duet** | Developer tooling plugin. Orthogonal to the stack. |

### What gets archived

| Project | Absorbed by | Migration |
|---------|-------------|-----------|
| **Telos/Oracle** | Lineage | Move intent/ directory, update contracts |
| **Lore** | Lineage | Move registry/, retire bridge contract |
| **Flow** | Neo | Move state management, retire signal contract |
| **Mirror** | Convention | Document in Neo, archive repo |

### What's unaffected

| Project | Reason |
|---------|--------|
| Canary | Production app, independent |
| Agent-of-Empires | Rust TUI, independent |
| Geordi | API layer, reads from whatever the data layer is |
| l3m | Local LLM tooling, independent |
| Forge | Prototyping pipeline, independent |
| Tutor | Reference material, independent |

### After: 6 core projects

```
Lineage  â”€â”€â†’  Neo  â”€â”€â†’  Bach
(data)       (control)   (action)
   â†‘            â†‘
   â”‚            â”‚
Council      Ralph
(governance)  (loop)

Duet (tooling, orthogonal)
```

### The contracts simplify too

| Before | After |
|--------|-------|
| SIGNAL_CONTRACT (Ralph â†” Flow) | SIGNAL_CONTRACT (Ralph â†” Neo) |
| TASK_CONTRACT (Flow â†’ Bach) | TASK_CONTRACT (Neo â†’ Bach) |
| LINEAGE_CONTRACT | LINEAGE_CONTRACT (expanded) |
| ENTIRE_BRIDGE_CONTRACT (Lore) | Retired |
| CONTAINER_CONTRACT (Neo) | Stays |

### Migration order

Same pattern as the Praxis decomposition â€” inbox before sync:

```
1. Lineage absorbs Telos    (add intent/, update contract)
2. Lineage absorbs Lore     (add registry/, retire bridge contract)
3. Neo absorbs Flow          (move state management, update signal contract)
4. Archive Mirror            (document convention in Neo)
5. Update Geordi             (point reads at consolidated Lineage)
```

Each step is independently valuable. Stop at any point and the system still works.

file.content:
# Oracle - Intent and Goals Layer

Oracle transforms high-level outcomes into actionable work. It answers "why are we doing this?" and tracks progress toward goals, not just tasks.

## Stack Position

```
Oracle (this) - Goals, triggers, outcome tracking
    â†“ missions
Neo - Team management
    â†“ agents
Council - Coordination patterns
    â†“ work
Lore - Project registry
```

## Core Concepts

### Goals

High-level outcomes with success criteria.

```yaml
name: "Ship Feature X"
success_criteria:
  - "All tests passing"
  - "Coverage >= 80%"
  - "PR approved and merged"
deadline: "2026-02-15"
```

### Missions

Work packages generated from goals, sent to Neo for team execution.

### Triggers

Automation that initiates work:

- **Manual**: Direct invocation
- **Scheduled**: Cron-like timing
- **Event**: Git push, PR opened, file changed
- **Condition**: When metrics cross thresholds

## Key Commands

```bash
# Goals
oracle goal create "Ship Feature X"
oracle goal list --status active
oracle goal show <goal-id>

# Missions
oracle mission generate <goal-id>
oracle mission send <mission-id>

# Triggers
oracle trigger create --type schedule --cron "0 9 * * *"
oracle trigger list
oracle trigger run <trigger-id>

# Status
oracle status [<goal-id>]
oracle blockers
```

## Directory Layout

- `scripts/` - CLI commands
- `lib/` - Core logic (decomposition, tracking)
- `templates/` - Goal and trigger templates
- `triggers/` - Trigger implementations
- `goals/` - Active goal definitions
- `missions/` - Generated missions

## Integration Points

**Reads from Lore:**

- Project metadata and paths
- Team capabilities

**Sends to Neo:**

- Mission definitions
- Priority and deadlines

**Receives from Neo:**

- Completion signals
- Progress updates
- Blocker reports

## Key Principles

1. **Outcome-focused**: Track goal achievement, not just task completion
2. **Declarative**: Define "what" not "how" - let Oracle decompose
3. **Observable**: Clear progress, blockers, and timeline projections
4. **Automated**: Triggers reduce manual orchestration overhead

file.content:
# Lore - System Hub

You are entering the meta-layer that coordinates all projects in `~/dev`.

## Quick Navigation

| Need                        | Location                              |
| --------------------------- | ------------------------------------- |
| Find a project              | `~/dev/mani.yaml`                     |
| Project metadata            | `registry/metadata.yaml`              |
| Understand clusters         | `registry/clusters.yaml`              |
| Cross-project relationships | `registry/relationships.yaml`         |
| Full architecture           | `SYSTEM.md`                           |
| Ecosystem architecture      | `~/dev/council/mainstay/ecosystem.md` |
| Reusable patterns           | `patterns/`                           |
| Operational checklist       | `context/CHECKLIST.md`                |
| Current handoff state       | `context/HANDOFF.md`                  |

## Architecture: mani + lore

**mani** knows _what exists_. **Lore** knows _why it matters_.

- **mani** (`~/dev/mani.yaml`): project names, paths, tags. Use mani to list, filter, and run commands across repos.
- **lore** (`registry/`): roles, contracts, cluster choreography, dependency rationale, context assembly. Use lore when you need the story behind a project.

```
~/dev/mani.yaml          (source of truth for project existence)
    |
    +-- mani CLI             list, filter, exec, TUI
    |
~/dev/lore/
    +-- registry/
    |   +-- metadata.yaml    role, contracts, components, links
    |   +-- clusters.yaml    pipeline choreography, data flow, principles
    |   +-- relationships.yaml  rich dependency metadata (sole dep source)
    +-- scripts/
        +-- lore-cli.sh   show, context, validate, sync
```

### Tag encoding in mani.yaml

See the [tag encoding table in README.md](README.md#tag-encoding).

## Active Clusters

- **orchestration**: Oracle (intent) + Lore (registry) + Neo (teams) + Lineage (memory)
- **council**: Flow (state) + Bach (workers), under Claude Code agent teams harness

## Commands

```bash
# List and filter projects (mani)
mani list projects                              # all projects
mani list projects --tags type:orchestrator      # filter by type
mani list projects --tags cluster:council        # filter by cluster
mani list projects --tags agents                 # filter by free tag
mani list projects --tags "lang:rust"            # filter by language

# Lore enrichment
./scripts/lore-cli.sh show <project>          # enriched project details
./scripts/lore-cli.sh context <project>       # assembled context for agent onboarding

# Validation
./scripts/lore-cli.sh validate                # check registry consistency
./scripts/lore-cli.sh sync                    # warn if metadata.yaml references missing from mani

# Git operations across projects
mani exec --all git status -s                    # status across all projects
```

## Tooling

Scripts require Go yq (`/opt/homebrew/bin/yq` v4.52+), jq (v1.7+), and mani (`brew install mani`).
The `yqj` helper bridges yq's YAML parsing with jq expressions -- all query logic uses jq syntax.
Do NOT use python-yq; it has incompatible flags.

## Your Role Here

Lore does NOT execute work. It:

- Provides system-wide context to agents
- Maintains metadata, clusters, and relationships
- Documents patterns for cross-project consistency
- Tracks system-level decisions and handoffs

## Before Making Changes

1. Read `SYSTEM.md` for the full architecture
2. Check `registry/relationships.yaml` for dependencies
3. Review `patterns/` for established conventions
4. Update `context/HANDOFF.md` when handing off

## Cross-Project Conventions

- Conventional commits with Strunk's-style body (see ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md)
- CLAUDE.md is the agent entry point in each project
- Never use emdashes (-) in documentation
- Configuration: TOML for config, YAML for registries

## When to Update What

**Edit `~/dev/mani.yaml`** (mani's file) when:

- A new project is created in `~/dev`
- A project's path, description, or tags change

**Edit lore files** (`registry/`) when:

- A project needs role/contracts/components (edit `metadata.yaml`)
- A project joins or leaves a cluster (edit `clusters.yaml` + add `cluster:` tag in mani.yaml)
- Cross-project dependencies change (edit `relationships.yaml`)
- A new pattern emerges worth documenting

Record significant decisions in Lineage:

```bash
~/dev/lineage/lineage.sh remember "<decision>" --rationale "<why>" --tags "lore,<topic>"
```

## Pending Plans

Check `plans/` for work items ready for pickup. Current plans:

- `plan-wire-lineage-functions.md` -- Wire unused Lineage client functions

## Project Entry Pattern

When an agent enters a project from lore:

1. Read the project's CLAUDE.md first
2. Check cluster membership (orchestration? council?)
3. Understand adjacent interfaces if clustered
4. Work within the project's conventions

    21â†’â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

    27â†’â”‚                          BACH                               â”‚
    28â†’â”‚                (stateless worker execution)                 â”‚
    29â†’â”‚                                                             â”‚
    30â†’â”‚   Receives envelope â†’ Executes specialty â†’ Returns result  â”‚
    31â†’â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    32â†’```
    33â†’
    34â†’## Components
    35â†’
    36â†’| Project   | Responsibility                     | State                  |
    37â†’| --------- | ---------------------------------- | ---------------------- |
    38â†’| **Ralph** | Drive the loop until completion    | Stateless (reads Flow) |
    39â†’| **Flow**  | Track progress, delegate work      | `.flow/state.json`     |
    40â†’| **Bach**  | Execute tasks via worker templates | Stateless              |
    41â†’
    42â†’## Contracts
    43â†’
    44â†’| Contract | Location                                          | Defines                                                             |
    45â†’| -------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------- |

    47â†’| Task     | [bach/TASK_CONTRACT.md](../bach/TASK_CONTRACT.md) | Flow â†’ Bach: task envelope, result envelope, worker vocabulary      |
    48â†’
    49â†’## Data Flow
    50â†’
    51â†’1. **Ralph** reads `.flow/state.json`
    52â†’2. **Ralph** checks `signal.action` and `signal.ready`
    53â†’3. **Ralph** invokes `/flow:{action}` command
    54â†’4. **Flow** updates state, delegates tasks to Bach workers
    55â†’5. **Bach** workers execute and return result envelopes
    56â†’6. **Flow** updates task status, writes new signal
    57â†’7. **Ralph** exits, loop feeds prompt back
    58â†’8. Repeat until `signal.action == "none"`
    59â†’
    60â†’## Signal Lifecycle
    61â†’
    62â†’```
    63â†’init â†’ plan â†’ [research] â†’ execute-phase â†’ [review] â†’ complete
    64â†’                  â†‘              â”‚
    65â†’                  â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    66â†’                   (if unknowns)
    67â†’```
    68â†’
    69â†’## Worker Delegation
    70â†’

    72â†’
    73â†’```
    74â†’Task in phase
    75â†’     â”‚
    76â†’     â–¼
    77â†’â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
    78â†’â”‚  Build envelope â”‚ â† id, worker, task, context
    79â†’â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    80â†’         â”‚
    81â†’         â–¼

    83â†’â”‚  Select worker  â”‚ â† coder, researcher, reviewer, tester
    84â†’â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    85â†’         â”‚
    86â†’         â–¼
    87â†’â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
    88â†’â”‚  Invoke via     â”‚

    90â†’â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    91â†’         â”‚
    92â†’         â–¼

    94â†’â”‚  Parse result   â”‚ â† status, summary, artifacts
    95â†’â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
    96â†’         â”‚

   101â†’```

   103â†’## Interface Boundaries

   106â†’

   108â†’| --------- | ------------------------------ | -------------------------- |
   109â†’| Ralph     | Signal contract, Flow commands | Bach exists, task details  |
   110â†’| Flow      | Both contracts, full state     | How workers execute        |
   111â†’| Bach      | Task contract, its specialty   | Project state, other tasks |
   112â†’
   113â†’## Running the System
   114â†’
   115â†’```bash
   116â†’# In a project with .flow/ initialized
   117â†’/ralph-loop ".planning/FLOW_PROMPT.md" --max-iterations 100 --completion-promise "MILESTONE_COMPLETE"
   118â†’```
   119â†’
   120â†’Or headless:
   121â†’
   122â†’```bash
   123â†’ralph --prompt FLOW_PROMPT.md
   124â†’```
   125â†’
   126â†’## Evolution
   127â†’
   128â†’The narrow interfaces allow independent evolution:
   129â†’
   130â†’- **New workers**: Add to Bach, update Flow's worker vocabulary
   131â†’- **New signals**: Add to Flow, update Ralph's dispatch table
   132â†’- **New loop modes**: Add to Ralph, Flow doesn't change
   133â†’
   134â†’When integration gains identity (tests accumulate, external users appear), consider a dedicated repo. Until then, Flow is the hub.
   135â†’

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

# Orchestration Architecture

Three projects, narrow interfaces, one data flow.

```
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                          RALPH                              â”‚
â”‚                  (autonomous loop runner)                   â”‚
â”‚                                                             â”‚
â”‚   Reads state.json â†’ Invokes /flow:* â†’ Exits â†’ Repeats     â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                              â”‚
                              â”‚ SIGNAL_CONTRACT.md
                              â”‚ (state.json with signal field)
                              â–¼
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                          FLOW                               â”‚
â”‚              (state management & orchestration)             â”‚
â”‚                                                             â”‚
â”‚   Tracks milestones â†’ Manages phases â†’ Delegates tasks     â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                              â”‚
                              â”‚ TASK_CONTRACT.md
                              â”‚ (task envelope â†’ result envelope)
                              â–¼
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                          BACH                               â”‚
â”‚                (stateless worker execution)                 â”‚
â”‚                                                             â”‚
â”‚   Receives envelope â†’ Executes specialty â†’ Returns result  â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
```

## Components

| Project   | Responsibility                     | State                  |
| --------- | ---------------------------------- | ---------------------- |
| **Ralph** | Drive the loop until completion    | Stateless (reads Flow) |
| **Flow**  | Track progress, delegate work      | `.flow/state.json`     |
| **Bach**  | Execute tasks via worker templates | Stateless              |

## Contracts

| Contract | Location                                          | Defines                                                             |
| -------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Signal   | [SIGNAL_CONTRACT.md](./SIGNAL_CONTRACT.md)        | Ralph â†” Flow: state.json schema, signal vocabulary, iteration logic |
| Task     | [bach/TASK_CONTRACT.md](../bach/TASK_CONTRACT.md) | Flow â†’ Bach: task envelope, result envelope, worker vocabulary      |

## Data Flow

1. **Ralph** reads `.flow/state.json`
2. **Ralph** checks `signal.action` and `signal.ready`
3. **Ralph** invokes `/flow:{action}` command
4. **Flow** updates state, delegates tasks to Bach workers
5. **Bach** workers execute and return result envelopes
6. **Flow** updates task status, writes new signal
7. **Ralph** exits, loop feeds prompt back
8. Repeat until `signal.action == "none"`

## Signal Lifecycle

```
init â†’ plan â†’ [research] â†’ execute-phase â†’ [review] â†’ complete
                  â†‘              â”‚
                  â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
                   (if unknowns)
```

## Worker Delegation

Flow's `/flow:execute` builds task envelopes and spawns Bach workers:

```
Task in phase
     â”‚
     â–¼
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚  Build envelope â”‚ â† id, worker, task, context
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
         â”‚
         â–¼
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚  Select worker  â”‚ â† coder, researcher, reviewer, tester
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
         â”‚
         â–¼
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚  Invoke via     â”‚
â”‚  Task tool      â”‚ â† Bach template + envelope
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
         â”‚
         â–¼
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚  Parse result   â”‚ â† status, summary, artifacts
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
         â”‚
         â–¼
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ Update state    â”‚ â† task complete/blocked/incapable
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
```

## Interface Boundaries

Each component knows only its adjacent interface:

| Component | Knows                          | Doesn't Know               |
| --------- | ------------------------------ | -------------------------- |
| Ralph     | Signal contract, Flow commands | Bach exists, task details  |
| Flow      | Both contracts, full state     | How workers execute        |
| Bach      | Task contract, its specialty   | Project state, other tasks |

## Running the System

```bash
# In a project with .flow/ initialized
/ralph-loop ".planning/FLOW_PROMPT.md" --max-iterations 100 --completion-promise "MILESTONE_COMPLETE"
```

Or headless:

```bash
ralph --prompt FLOW_PROMPT.md
```

## Evolution

The narrow interfaces allow independent evolution:

- **New workers**: Add to Bach, update Flow's worker vocabulary
- **New signals**: Add to Flow, update Ralph's dispatch table
- **New loop modes**: Add to Ralph, Flow doesn't change

When integration gains identity (tests accumulate, external users appear), consider a dedicated repo. Until then, Flow is the hub.

file.content:
# Signal Contract: Harness â†” Flow

Harness reads. Flow writes. The contract is `state.json`.

## State Schema (Flow writes)

```json
{
  "status": "planning | researching | executing | blocked | complete",
  "currentMilestone": "v0.1",
  "currentPhase": 2,
  "blockers": [],
  "signal": {
    "action": "execute-phase",
    "target": "2",
    "ready": true
  }
}
```

## Signal Field (Harness reads)

| Field            | Type    | Purpose                               |
| ---------------- | ------- | ------------------------------------- |
| `signal.action`  | string  | Next Flow command to invoke           |
| `signal.target`  | string? | Argument for the command (phase, etc) |
| `signal.ready`   | boolean | Whether action can proceed            |
| `signal.blocked` | string? | Reason if not ready                   |

## Action Vocabulary

| `signal.action` | Harness invokes             | When                             |
| --------------- | --------------------------- | -------------------------------- |
| `init`          | `/flow:init`                | No state.json exists             |
| `plan`          | `/flow:plan`                | Goal set, no phases defined      |
| `plan-phase`    | `/flow:plan-phase {target}` | Phase needs task breakdown       |
| `research`      | `/flow:research`            | Unknowns identified              |
| `execute-phase` | `/flow:execute {target}`    | Phase ready, tasks pending       |
| `review`        | `/flow:review`              | Phase complete, needs validation |
| `complete`      | `/flow:complete`            | All phases done, audit clean     |
| `none`          | Exit loop                   | Nothing to do (blocked or done)  |

## Completion Signals

| Condition              | `status`   | `signal.action`  | Harness behavior                                     |
| ---------------------- | ---------- | ---------------- | ---------------------------------------------------- |
| Milestone complete     | `complete` | `none`           | Output `<promise>MILESTONE_COMPLETE</promise>`, exit |
| Blocked, can't proceed | `blocked`  | `none`           | Output blockers, exit                                |
| Work remains           | `*`        | `*` (not `none`) | Invoke action, continue loop                         |

## Harness Iteration Logic

```
1. Read .flow/state.json
2. If signal.action == "none":
     If status == "complete": output promise, exit
     Else: output blockers, exit
3. If signal.ready == false:
     Output signal.blocked, exit
4. Invoke /flow:{signal.action} {signal.target}
5. Exit (loop feeds back)
```

## Flow's Responsibility

After every `/flow:*` command, Flow must:

1. Update `status` to reflect current state
2. Set `signal.action` to the logical next step
3. Set `signal.ready` based on dependencies/blockers
4. Persist to `state.json`

## Example States

**Fresh project:**

```json
{
  "status": "planning",
  "signal": { "action": "plan", "ready": true }
}
```

**Phase 2 ready to execute:**

```json
{
  "status": "executing",
  "currentPhase": 2,
  "signal": { "action": "execute-phase", "target": "2", "ready": true }
}
```

**Blocked on external dependency:**

```json
{
  "status": "blocked",
  "blockers": ["Waiting for API credentials from infra team"],
  "signal": {
    "action": "none",
    "ready": false,
    "blocked": "external dependency"
  }
}
```

**Done:**

```json
{
  "status": "complete",
  "signal": { "action": "none", "ready": true }
}
```

content.text: Good â€” now I have the full picture. Steps 1+2 both modify Lineage's shared files (`lineage.sh`, contract), so one agent handles both sequentially. Step 4 is independent. Step 3 (rename) waits for 1+2.

input.description: Consolidate ecosystem: Telos+Lore into Lineage, Flow into Neo, rename Lineage to Lore

input.subject: Absorb Telos and Lore into Lineage
input.description: Step 1: Add intent/ component to Lineage (absorbing Oracle/Telos goals and missions). Step 2: Add registry/ component to Lineage (absorbing Lore's registry YAML files). Both steps modify lineage.sh and LINEAGE_CONTRACT.md so must be done sequentially by one agent. Study Oracle (~/dev/oracle/) and Lore (~/dev/lore/) structures. Implement in Lineage's bash conventions. Reference ~/dev/praxis/ for design intent on intent/.
input.activeForm: Absorbing Telos and Lore into Lineage

content.content: Task #1 created successfully: Absorb Telos and Lore into Lineage

task.subject: Absorb Telos and Lore into Lineage

input.subject: Absorb Flow into Neo
input.description: Move Flow's state management and orchestration into Neo. Neo already has sync/promote/start scripts. Add Flow's milestone/phase/task state tracking, signal contract support, and orchestration commands (plan, execute, status, research, review, complete). Study ~/dev/cli/flow/ for the current implementation â€” commands/, agents/, skills/, SIGNAL_CONTRACT.md, ARCHITECTURE.md. Ralph currently invokes /flow:* commands â€” after this, Ralph invokes Neo equivalents. Implement in Neo's shell conventions. Move SIGNAL_CONTRACT.md and TASK_CONTRACT.md references to Neo. Update Neo's CLAUDE.md.

content.content: Task #2 created successfully: Absorb Flow into Neo

input.subject: Rename Lineage to Lore
input.description: After Telos and Lore are absorbed, rename the consolidated project from Lineage to Lore. This touches: repo directory (~/dev/lineage/ â†’ ~/dev/lore/), CLI (lineage.sh â†’ lore.sh, all commands from 'lineage X' to 'lore X'), contract (LINEAGE_CONTRACT.md â†’ LORE_CONTRACT.md), Neo's scripts (all lineage.sh calls become lore.sh), ~/.zshrc alias, graph nodes, every CLAUDE.md that mentions Lineage, council docs. The current ~/dev/lore/ directory must be archived or moved first since it currently holds the old Lore project.

content.content: Task #3 created successfully: Rename Lineage to Lore
Updated task #3 blockedBy

input.prompt:
You are a teammate on team "grand-simplification". Your name is "lineage-consolidator".

YOUR TASK (Task #1): Absorb Telos (Oracle) and Lore into Lineage. Two steps, done sequentially.

## Step 1: Absorb Telos (Oracle) into Lineage

Oracle (~/dev/oracle/) manages goals and missions. Add an `intent/` component to Lineage that handles this.

Study first:
- ~/dev/oracle/CLAUDE.md â€” understand concepts (goals, missions, triggers)
- ~/dev/oracle/goals/ â€” see existing goal YAML format
- ~/dev/oracle/scripts/goal.sh, ~/dev/oracle/scripts/mission.sh â€” understand CLI commands
- ~/dev/oracle/lib/ â€” understand core logic
- ~/dev/praxis/store.py lines 95-103 â€” Praxis prototype for intent storage

Create in ~/dev/lineage/:
- `intent/data/` directory (with .gitkeep)
- `intent/lib/intent.sh` â€” core functions: create_goal, list_goals, get_goal, create_mission, list_missions
- Wire into lineage.sh: `lineage goal create "..."`, `lineage goal list`, `lineage mission generate <goal-id>`
- Goals stored as individual YAML files (matching Oracle's format) in intent/data/goals/
- Missions stored as YAML in intent/data/missions/

Follow Lineage conventions: set -euo pipefail, quoted expansions, SCRIPT_DIR/DATA_DIR pattern. Study journal/lib/journal.sh for the pattern.

## Step 2: Absorb Lore into Lineage

Lore (~/dev/lore/) maintains the project registry. Add a `registry/` component to Lineage.

Study first:

input.prompt:
You are a teammate on team "grand-simplification". Your name is "neo-consolidator".

YOUR TASK (Task #2): Absorb Flow's orchestration into Neo.

Flow (~/dev/cli/flow/) is a Claude Code plugin that manages milestones, phases, and task state. Neo (~/dev/neo/) already manages teams and has sync/promote/start scripts. Merge Flow's state management into Neo.

Study first:
- ~/dev/cli/flow/CLAUDE.md â€” understand Flow's structure
- ~/dev/cli/flow/ARCHITECTURE.md â€” the three-layer architecture (Ralph â†’ Flow â†’ Bach)
- ~/dev/cli/flow/SIGNAL_CONTRACT.md â€” how Ralph talks to Flow
- ~/dev/cli/bach/TASK_CONTRACT.md â€” how Flow talks to Bach
- ~/dev/cli/flow/commands/ â€” init.md, plan.md, execute.md, status.md, research.md, review.md, complete.md
- ~/dev/cli/flow/skills/flow-methodology/SKILL.md â€” the orchestration methodology
- ~/dev/neo/CLAUDE.md â€” Neo's current structure
- ~/dev/neo/scripts/ â€” existing sync.sh, promote.sh, start.sh

What to create in ~/dev/neo/:
1. Copy SIGNAL_CONTRACT.md from Flow into Neo (update references: "Flow" â†’ "Neo" throughout)
2. Copy TASK_CONTRACT.md from Bach into Neo (or reference it â€” Bach keeps its copy)
3. Add orchestration scripts to ~/dev/neo/scripts/:
   - `plan.sh` â€” decompose a mission into milestones and phases (reads from Flow's methodology)
   - `execute.sh` â€” run current phase tasks, delegate to Bach workers
   - `status.sh` â€” show current state (milestone, phase, tasks, blockers)
   - `review.sh` â€” validate phase completion
4. Add state management:
   - Neo already has `state/` directory â€” use it for `.neo/state.json` (same schema as Flow's .flow/state.json)
   - Or use the existing state/ directory convention
5. Update ~/dev/neo/CLAUDE.md:
   - Add orchestration commands section
   - Reference both contracts
   - Update architecture description: Neo now does teams + orchestration + sync/promote
6. Update ~/dev/neo/README.md:
   - Add orchestration section explaining the Ralph â†’ Neo â†’ Bach flow

The key insight: Ralph will invoke Neo commands instead of Flow commands. The signal contract stays the same â€” just the target changes from /flow:* to Neo scripts.

Implement in Neo's shell convention. These are scripts, not Claude Code plugin commands.

Do NOT commit â€” just make the changes.
When done, mark Task #2 as completed and message the team lead.

message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="neo-consolidator" color="green" summary="Task #2 complete: Flow orchestration absorbed into Neo">
Task #2 complete â€” Flow's orchestration is absorbed into Neo. Here's what I created/modified:

**New files in ~/dev/neo/:**

1. `SIGNAL_CONTRACT.md` â€” Ralph â†” Neo signal contract (adapted from Flow, all references updated: Flow â†’ Neo, Harness â†’ Ralph, /flow:* commands â†’ Neo scripts)

2. `TASK_CONTRACT.md` â€” Neo â†’ Bach task contract (adapted from Bach's copy, all references updated: Flow â†’ Neo, schema file paths point to local `schemas/`)

3. `schemas/task-envelope.json` â€” Task envelope JSON Schema (Neoâ†’Bach)

4. `schemas/result-envelope.json` â€” Result envelope JSON Schema (Bachâ†’Neo)

5. `scripts/plan.sh` â€” Three modes:
   - `--init`: Initialize `.neo/` with goal, scope, constraints (interactive)
   - (no flags): Full planning â€” milestones â†’ phases (interactive)
   - `--phase N`: Break a specific phase into tasks with dependencies, workers, acceptance criteria

6. `scripts/execute.sh` â€” Reads state.json, builds execution waves from dependency DAG, writes task envelopes to `.neo/envelopes/<task-id>.json` for Bach dispatch. One wave per invocation (Ralph loops back for the next). Updates signal appropriately.

7. `scripts/review.sh` â€” Two modes:
   - (no flags): Phase review â€” checks task completion against criteria, verdicts: APPROVED / NEEDS_REWORK / BLOCKED
   - `--final`: Milestone completion audit â€” verifies all phases, marks milestone complete or returns to first incomplete phase

**Modified files:**

8. `scripts/status.sh` â€” Now shows orchestration state (goal, milestone, phase, signal, task counts, blockers) when `.neo/state.json` exists, before the existing team/agent status output.

9. `CLAUDE.md` â€” Added: Architecture section (Ralph â†’ Neo â†’ Bach), contracts table, signal lifecycle, orchestration scripts reference with usage examples, orchestration state directory layout.

10. `README.md` â€” Added: Architecture diagram, layer responsibility table, orchestration section with all script usage, signal lifecycle, contracts table. Renamed existing section to "Sync-Promote-Start" for clarity.

**Key design decisions:**
- State lives in `.neo/` (per-project, gitignored) â€” same pattern as Flow's `.flow/`
- Scripts use Neo's existing shell convention (not Claude Code plugin commands)
- execute.sh writes task envelopes to `.neo/envelopes/` for the caller to dispatch to Bach
- One wave per execute.sh invocation â€” Ralph loops back for subsequent waves
- All scripts log to `logs/orchestration.log`
- Signal contract vocabulary maps directly: Ralph invokes `neo plan.sh`, `neo execute.sh N`, `neo review.sh`, `neo review.sh --final` instead of `/flow:*` commands
</teammate-message>

input.prompt:
You are a teammate on team "grand-simplification". Your name is "renamer".

YOUR TASK (Task #3): Rename the Lineage project to Lore.

Lineage has absorbed Oracle (intent/) and the old Lore (registry/). Now the consolidated project takes the name "Lore." The current ~/dev/lore/ directory holds the OLD Lore project that was absorbed â€” it needs to be archived first.

## Step-by-step:

### 1. Archive the old Lore
```bash
mv ~/dev/lore ~/dev/_archive/lore-old
```

### 2. Rename the directory
```bash
mv ~/dev/lineage ~/dev/lore
```

### 3. Rename the CLI
In ~/dev/lore/:
- Rename `lineage.sh` â†’ `lore.sh`
- Inside `lore.sh`: replace all references to "lineage" with "lore" in user-facing strings (help text, command names, error messages). Keep internal variable names if they don't surface to users.

### 4. Rename the contract
- Rename `LINEAGE_CONTRACT.md` â†’ `LORE_CONTRACT.md`
- Inside the file: update title, description, and command examples from `lineage` to `lore`

### 5. Update CLAUDE.md
In ~/dev/lore/CLAUDE.md:
- Update project title from "Lineage" to "Lore"
- Update all `lineage` command references to `lore`
- Update contract reference from LINEAGE_CONTRACT.md to LORE_CONTRACT.md

### 6. Update Neo's references
In ~/dev/neo/:
- `scripts/sync.sh` â€” change `lineage.sh` calls to point to `~/dev/lore/lore.sh`
- `scripts/promote.sh` â€” same
- `scripts/start.sh` â€” same
- `CLAUDE.md` â€” update any lineage references to lore
- `README.md` â€” update `lineage observe` â†’ `lore observe`, `lineage remember` â†’ `lore remember`, etc.

### 7. Update ~/.zshrc alias
Change:
```
alias lineage='~/dev/lineage/lineage.sh'
```
To:
```
alias lore='~/dev/lore/lore.sh'
```

### 8. Update internal lib references
In ~/dev/lore/lib/ â€” any scripts that reference LINEAGE_DIR or lineage paths need updating. Check:
- `lib/ingest.sh` â€” LINEAGE_DIR variable
- `graph/lib/nodes.sh` â€” any lineage references
- `transfer/lib/snapshot.sh` â€” any lineage references
- `journal/journal.sh` â€” any lineage references
- `inbox/lib/inbox.sh` â€” any lineage references
- `intent/lib/intent.sh` â€” any lineage references
- `registry/lib/registry.sh` â€” any lineage references

For internal variables like LINEAGE_DIR, rename to LORE_DIR or LORE_ROOT for consistency.

### 9. Update README.md
In ~/dev/lore/README.md â€” update project name and any lineage references.

## Important:
- Do NOT touch journal data (decisions.jsonl) â€” historical entries keep their original tags
- Do NOT touch graph data (graph.json) â€” node names stay as-is for now
- Do NOT touch patterns data â€” historical references stay
- Do NOT commit â€” just make all the changes
- Be thorough â€” grep for "lineage" and "Lineage" across ~/dev/lore/ and ~/dev/neo/ after changes to catch stragglers

When done, mark Task #3 as completed and message the team lead with a summary.

content.text:
Reflect on the work just completed in this conversation.

## What I Learned

Identify 2-4 concrete technical insights from this session:

- Patterns discovered or reinforced
- Gotchas or surprises encountered
- Techniques that worked well (or didn't)
- Connections to other parts of the codebase

Focus on _insights_, not a summary of actions taken.

## What to Think About Next

Surface 2-4 open threads worth considering:

- Unfinished work or TODOs
- Edge cases or risks not yet addressed
- Potential improvements or refactors
- Questions that came up but weren't resolved

Be specificâ€”name files, functions, or concepts rather than speaking abstractly.

---

After generating the retro, ask the user if any insights are worth persisting to auto memory. Use AskUserQuestion with options like "Yes, update MEMORY.md" and "No, just this session".

If yes, read the current MEMORY.md from the project's auto memory directory and intelligently merge the new insightsâ€”don't duplicate existing points, add new ones under the appropriate sections.

## What I Learned

**Prototypes dissolve, patterns survive.** Praxis was never meant to ship. It proved Sync-Promote-Execute in Python, then decomposed into plan files targeting existing repos in their native conventions (bash). The prototype's value was the pattern it validated, not the code it contained. This is now captured as a Lore pattern (`pat-092136-e3216f19`).

**Agents that share files can't run in parallel.** When lineage-consolidator needed to absorb both Telos and Lore, both steps touched `lineage.sh` and `LINEAGE_CONTRACT.md`. Splitting into two parallel agents would have caused merge conflicts. One agent doing both steps sequentially was the right call. The ad-hoc agent model makes this easy â€” you shape the prompt to the constraint.

**Timestamp-on-read is a silent bug.** `graph/lib/nodes.sh:add_node()` bumped `updated_at` every time a node was re-ingested with identical data, making `graph.json` perpetually dirty. The fix was a three-line comparison before writing. This pattern (compare-before-write) applies anywhere append-only data gets re-ingested â€” worth watching for in `registry/` now that Lore ingests from multiple sources.

**Rename scope explodes.** Renaming Lineage â†’ Lore touched 2 repos, ~/.zshrc, ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md, internal variables (LINEAGE_DIR â†’ LORE_DIR), function names, JSON keys, CLI help text, contract filenames, and README references. The renamer agent's final grep sweep for stragglers was essential â€” without it, half the cross-references would have been missed.

## What to Think About Next

**Uncommitted collateral in Lore.** `decisions.jsonl`, `session-example.json`, and `.entire/` were skipped during the commit. The first two keep getting damaged by session activity. Consider `.gitignore`-ing `transfer/data/sessions/session-example.json` or fixing whatever overwrites it. The `.entire/` directory is unexplained â€” investigate or remove.

**Flow and Ralph plugins still exist.** `~/dev/cli/flow/` and the ralph-loop plugin are still installed and active. Neo absorbed Flow's functionality but the plugin is still loadable. Disable or archive to prevent confusion â€” two systems offering the same orchestration commands.

**Geordi points at stale paths.** Geordi reads from Lineage, Lore, and Council. After the rename, its data paths are wrong. Check `~/dev/geordi/` for hardcoded `~/dev/lineage/` references.

**`mani.yaml` needs updating.** The project registry uses mani for cross-repo operations. Lineage â†’ Lore rename means the mani config at `~/dev/mani.yaml` has a stale entry. Lore's own `registry/data/metadata.yaml` may also reference old project names.

input.content:
# Duet Memory

## Ecosystem Architecture

The stack is five projects:

```
Lore  â†’  Neo  â†’  Bach
(data)  (control) (action)

Council (governance)
Duet (tooling)
```

- Lore (~/dev/lore/) â€” 7 components: journal, graph, patterns, transfer, inbox, intent, registry. CLI: `lore.sh`
- Neo (~/dev/neo/) â€” teams, orchestration (plan/execute/review), sync/promote/start
- Bach (~/dev/cli/bach/) â€” stateless worker templates (coder, researcher, reviewer, tester)
- Oracle archived â†’ absorbed into Lore as intent/
- Old Lore archived â†’ absorbed into Lore as registry/
- Flow absorbed into Neo (orchestration scripts + contracts)
- Lineage renamed to Lore (2026-02-14)

## Patterns

- **Prototypes dissolve.** Build a prototype to prove a pattern, then decompose into plan files targeting existing repos. The prototype is a catalyst, not a destination.
- **Compare before write.** When re-ingesting data, check if content changed before bumping timestamps. Prevents phantom diffs (see `graph/lib/nodes.sh:add_node()`).
- **Agents sharing files can't parallelize.** If two agents modify the same file (lineage.sh, a contract), use one agent sequentially. Shape the prompt to the constraint.
- **Rename scope explodes.** A project rename touches repos, aliases, internal variables, function names, JSON keys, CLIs, contracts, READMEs. Always grep for stragglers after.
- **Ad-hoc agents over premature definitions.** Start agents ad hoc. Use `lore observe` to log recurring patterns. Promote to Bach worker template after three sightings.

## Gotchas

- `session-example.json` in Lore gets overwritten by session activity â€” perpetually dirty. Needs .gitignore or a fix.
- `decisions.jsonl` is append-only â€” never modify historical entries, even during renames.
- Duet plugin changes (plugin.json, new skills/commands) require Claude Code restart. Existing skill content changes take effect on next invocation.
- The `lineage` alias in .zshrc was replaced with `lore`. Neo scripts aliased as `neo-sync`, `neo-promote`, `neo-start`.

content.text:
Reflect on the work just completed in this conversation.

## What I Learned

Identify 2-4 concrete technical insights from this session:

- Patterns discovered or reinforced
- Gotchas or surprises encountered
- Techniques that worked well (or didn't)
- Connections to other parts of the codebase

Focus on _insights_, not a summary of actions taken.

## What to Think About Next

Surface 2-4 open threads worth considering:

- Unfinished work or TODOs
- Edge cases or risks not yet addressed
- Potential improvements or refactors
- Questions that came up but weren't resolved

Be specificâ€”name files, functions, or concepts rather than speaking abstractly.

---

After generating the retro, ask the user if any insights are worth persisting to auto memory. Use AskUserQuestion with options like "Yes, update MEMORY.md" and "No, just this session".

If yes, read the current MEMORY.md from the project's auto memory directory and intelligently merge the new insightsâ€”don't duplicate existing points, add new ones under the appropriate sections.

## What I Learned

**Teams scale the session, not the complexity.** This session spawned 13 agents across 4 teams. The pattern that worked: one team per concern (implementation, polish, consolidation), tasks with explicit dependencies, parallel where possible, sequential where files overlap. The team abstraction mapped cleanly to the work â€” no agent stepped on another.

**Disabling beats deleting for plugins.** Setting a plugin to `false` in `enabledPlugins` is the right move over removing symlinks or archives. It's reversible, visible in the config, and doesn't require cleanup. Three plugins disabled this session (frontend-design, ralph-loop, flow) â€” all one-line changes.

**The grand simplification was mostly a documentation exercise.** The actual code changes (absorbing intent/, registry/, orchestration scripts) were modest. The real work was updating every cross-reference â€” CLAUDE.md files, contracts, README tables, aliases, variable names. Architecture decisions are cheap to make, expensive to propagate.

**Sweep after agents, always.** The `/sweep` command caught `session-example.json` damage, `decisions.jsonl` collateral, and pre-existing dirty `graph.json` â€” all from agent side-effects that would have been committed silently. Running sweep between agent work and commits prevented three bad commits.

## What to Think About Next

**Lore and Neo commits aren't pushed.** Two substantial commits (`a5a7344` in Lore, `3f3c638` in Neo) plus the Duet vamp update are sitting unpushed. The Lore commit is the big one â€” 32 files, full consolidation + rename.

**Geordi and mani.yaml have stale references.** Geordi reads from `~/dev/lineage/` which no longer exists. `~/dev/mani.yaml` still lists Lineage as a project. `lore/registry/data/metadata.yaml` may reference old project names internally. These will break the next time anything queries the registry.

**Bach's TASK_CONTRACT.md now has two copies.** One in `~/dev/cli/bach/TASK_CONTRACT.md` (original) and one in `~/dev/neo/TASK_CONTRACT.md` (copied during Flow absorption). Which is canonical? If Bach owns the contract, Neo should reference it, not duplicate it.

**The `.entire/` directory in Lore is unexplained.** It appeared untracked and was skipped during commits. Could be from a previous agent session or an abandoned feature. Investigate before it gets accidentally committed.

# Duet Memory

## Ecosystem Architecture

The stack is five projects:

```
Lore  â†’  Neo  â†’  Bach
(data)  (control) (action)

Council (governance)
Duet (tooling)
```

- Lore (~/dev/lore/) â€” 7 components: journal, graph, patterns, transfer, inbox, intent, registry. CLI: `lore.sh`
- Neo (~/dev/neo/) â€” teams, orchestration (plan/execute/review), sync/promote/start
- Bach (~/dev/cli/bach/) â€” stateless worker templates (coder, researcher, reviewer, tester)
- Oracle archived â†’ absorbed into Lore as intent/
- Old Lore archived â†’ absorbed into Lore as registry/
- Flow absorbed into Neo (orchestration scripts + contracts)
- Lineage renamed to Lore (2026-02-14)

## Patterns

- **Prototypes dissolve.** Build a prototype to prove a pattern, then decompose into plan files targeting existing repos. The prototype is a catalyst, not a destination.
- **Compare before write.** When re-ingesting data, check if content changed before bumping timestamps. Prevents phantom diffs (see `graph/lib/nodes.sh:add_node()`).
- **Agents sharing files can't parallelize.** If two agents modify the same file (lineage.sh, a contract), use one agent sequentially. Shape the prompt to the constraint.
- **Rename scope explodes.** A project rename touches repos, aliases, internal variables, function names, JSON keys, CLIs, contracts, READMEs. Always grep for stragglers after.
- **Ad-hoc agents over premature definitions.** Start agents ad hoc. Use `lore observe` to log recurring patterns. Promote to Bach worker template after three sightings.

## Gotchas

- `session-example.json` in Lore gets overwritten by session activity â€” perpetually dirty. Needs .gitignore or a fix.
- `decisions.jsonl` is append-only â€” never modify historical entries, even during renames.
- Duet plugin changes (plugin.json, new skills/commands) require Claude Code restart. Existing skill content changes take effect on next invocation.
- The `lineage` alias in .zshrc was replaced with `lore`. Neo scripts aliased as `neo-sync`, `neo-promote`, `neo-start`.

- **Disable beats delete for plugins.** Set to `false` in `enabledPlugins` rather than removing symlinks. Reversible, visible, no cleanup. Disabled: frontend-design, ralph-loop, flow.
